37997304.review:
I hesitated to buy this game, as it looked like pricey melodrama at a glance. I was a fool; it's worth it. 

Nightshade is, without question or doubt, my favorite game in this genre. Over the past year, I think I've played the bulk of the (localized) big hitters of otome: Amnesia, Hakuoki, a host of other Idea Factory / Otomate offerings on Vita (Norn9, Code Realize, Period Cube, Collar Malice, Bad Apple Wars, etc). I've played indie projects-- Cinderella Phenomenon, Cinders, Rose of Winter, Hustle Cat, Hatoful Boyfriend. Many I liked; some I loathed (Ozmafia!, lookin' at you). Nightshade, in my opinion, stands apart from them all, particularly for its well-developed and motivated characters, intelligently supported (if still unapologetically soapy) plot, lovely, lovely art, and inoffensive, even pleasant, sound design.

More detail:

To start, I really appreciate the protagonist, Enju. By necessity, the player character in the majority of romantic visual novels is a cypher best, if not solely, described as a Nice Girl. She wishes to avoid making waves, she wants to please everyone, she's shy but loves her friends: she is a perfectly normal, extremely contrived, HGTV nondescript beige intended for any player to step into and feel more or less at home. Moreover, to work through setting up the story's exposition, she must be oddly unfamiliar with the world she inhabits, unable to fend for herself (not to say incompetent, but...), and generally know as little as possible about anything. This narrative ignorance is even more crucial in the context of the character's relationships: to maximize the story's romantic arc, she must be in some conflict with the object of her affection, and since she's a Nice Girl, that restriction means conflict must usually come from her exaggerated modesty and shyness, and/or the gentleman's being Not Nice. Suffice to say: there's a narrative reason for all the bouts of convenient amnesia in these games, and there's likewise a reason for those tsundere lads that make Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy look like a sweet social butterfly. 

Enju is unquestionably a Nice Girl. But here's the thing that Nightshade does best, in part because I rarely see it done anywhere else: while Enju bears a superficial resemblance to her sisters in the genre, unlike many of them, she is a well-developed character with reasoned basis for those traits. Instead of incompetent, she is inexperienced; instead of merely ignorant, she is sheltered; instead of vague helplessness, she is tripped up by her own insecurities. That might sound like splitting hairs, until you are asked to find the trait relatable-- I'd argue that there's hope for a strong arc in a flawed character that is inexperienced, sheltered, and insecure, thrust into a harsh world beyond their ken; an incompetent, ignorant, and helpless character has a more bleak outlook, and I would consider them less "flawed" than flat and underdeveloped. Enju feels like a person, and if her starting point is inauspicious, she has a good distance to travel on her journey in character as much as geography.

This extends to every part of the writing, character and narrative both. No one in this game is perfect. The best shinobi of all time isn't going to have the best social skills; the cleverest flirt isn't going to be right in each assessment; that childhood friend that sets out to protect you from anything and everything bad is really doing you a disservice. This isn't a game that relies on a deus ex machina to save the day (mostly), and it doesn't assume that romance is summarized by a nice kiss at the end of a story-long misunderstanding: these characters have to get to know one another, develop trust, and we, the player, have to care about it. 

To that end, the story is easy to follow, and everyone has a full motive when they take an action. There's no weird technology from the future that's really the past, no vampires, no magical girls, no amnesia. There's death in this game, and it has heft and consequences, [spoiler]not least when Enju herself kills someone[/spoiler]. Depending on who Enju is running with, tragedy may well lace even an otherwise officially "happy" ending. But none of the drama feels like it's just for show here, to me: when you take the characters given-- flawed individuals with histories that extend beyond the start of the game and desires that exist outside of their pants-- and put them into the narrative, what follows are the consequences of specific personalities, with different motives, morality, values, and abilities, tested in specific ways. No route is wrong, no route is ‘golden’. Some routes, friends die; in some, the bad guy gets away. 

In sum: Nightshade is that rare, special otome that is complex in a good way, with a layered but tidy plot and well developed characters, not excluding the player character. The romance and the plot are balanced and pleasantly nuanced. It isn't the greatest love story ever told, but I'd gladly argue it's the best I've found in this medium.

Personal ramblings:

I can’t get this game out of my head. 
I’m listening to the OST non-stop and I can’t stop thinking about it. 
It’s really, truly, one of the best otome games out there.  
And I’m not just talking in terms of plot or characters. I’m talking in terms of everything. The combination of everything together was simply divine. 

I didn’t think it would hit be in the feels - both happy and sad - as much as it has, but it surpassed it all.  

This game has been on my Steam wishlist for a while until a few days ago when I decided to play it on a whim.  

I’m so glad I did because it took my breathe away. 

This game is a Japanese PSvita game that is now available in both English and Japanese on Steam. 

I HIGHLY recommend you play it. 
The common route may be a bit slow-paced, but trust me. Once you get into the individual routes you’re in for the shock - and happiness - of your life.  

I’m going to break it into categories to try to make some more sense about how fantastic this game is. 
So… whether you’ve played it or not, I hope you enjoy (:

The Plot:

The story follows our heroine, Enju (name can be changed but otherwise will be voiced) - born in the union between two clans. Being the leader’s daughter, she’s the princess of her village. But she’s also a shinobi (Ninja). Or at least, she desperately wants to be. 

There’s nothing Enju wants more than prove her worth to her village. 
When our story begins, she finally gets her chance. She, along with a few of her friends, are to be set on a mission in the city of Kyo. 
But things are not what they seem. And something terrible hides in the shadows. 
Who will Enju become? And who will she choose to go on this journey with her?

The common route starts slow and steady with a few action-scenes in between. It consists on 4 chapters. The choices you make during those times will decide which guy you’ll end up with.  
The individual routes are fast-paced and very… shocking. You’ll laugh, you’ll cry, you’ll love, you’ll feel. For everyone in this game. 

I suggest you save the game in the beginning of each new chapter, as well as Quick save whenever presented with a choice in case you haven’t chosen the “right” one and want to go back to change it. 

You’ll know you made the “right” choice when you see glowing flowers in front of your chosen character. 

In the common route, the character you earn most affection (flowers) with is the one you’ll end up with. 

The plot of this game sounds easy-enough, but trust me when I say you will not… see what’s coming. 

Prepare yourselves. 

The Characters:

Hanzo: The strongest shinobi of his time. Believes in following the mission, no matter what. Is harsh, yet kind. Is serious, yet boyish. Gives you space to grow into yourself, yet is there whenever you need him. 

My thoughts: Hnazo was the best route of this game. And one of the best characters I’ve ever seen in otome games. 
I had a feeling he was going to be a good one, I just had no idea he was going to blow me away. 

They are, simply put, the best for each other. In so many ways.

Kuroyuki: The childhood friend you haven’t seen in 8 years. He’s a tease, he’s funny, he’s forward, he’s endearing. But is he the same boy you used to know? And what exactly happened to him during those 8 long years? 

My thoughts: Kuroyuki’s route was… pretty dark. In terms of character-development and romance. That being said - I ended up falling for him (probably against my better judgment). 

i can’t say anything more here due to spoilers, but… just know you may experience annoyance, anger, but warm and fuzzy feelings at the end. 

Playing him after Hanzo may cause you to think “what the hell is wrong with you, Protagonist?!” since the protagonist acts differently in each route - but especially between Hanzo and Kuroyuki’s route. 
That being said, bear with it. It’s worth it (at least to me it was).

Goro: a flirtatious stranger you meet when you get to the city of Kyo. He’s always there to help, give advice, and make you smile. 

My thoughts: While Goro isn’t my usual type of otome guy, I found the lightheartedness of his route to be refreshing, much needed, and sweet. 
I would actually suggest playing him last if you wish you leave the game on the lightest of notes. 
I found his route to be a solid one and quite enjoyable (: 

Chojiro: Your cousin and teacher. He’s the one who taught you everything you know about being a shinobi. Much like Hanzo, he believes the way of the shinobi is finishing the mission no matter what, or die trying. 

My thoughts: Chojiro’s route was a good one, but could have been better. I found it to be lacking - but mostly overwhelming - in many ways. 
It’s… dark. Unlike with Kuroyuki, Chojiro’s route is dark in terms of plot. Prepare yourselves with some tissues. 

Gekkamaru: Your second childhood friend. The one who’s been with you all this time. He’s your bodyguard, your shield, and your protector. And he’s always there when you need him - and even when you don’t. He’s the only one who goes above and beyond for you - even when it’s not his own route. 

My thoughts: At first, I didn’t think I was going to like Gekkamaru’s route. He was way over-protective, as well as not my usual otome guy type. But. It took me one time seeing him in the other routes to know I was going to like him. And I was not mistaken. This guy is the only one that’s always there for the protagonist - no matter what. In every… single… route. 

I ended up loving Gekkamru very much so (!). He’s definitely one of the best routes of this game, and his route answers - and deals with - the most questions.

Recommended play-through (in terms of spoilers), would be: Hanzo - Goro - Kuroyuki - Chojiro - Gekkamaru. 
Of course, you can switch up between Hanzo and Goro as well as between Chojiro and Gekkamaru. 
Or, you can play the game however you like - although I actually suggest playing Chojiro and Gekkamaru routes last. 
Personally, I played the game like this: Hanzo - Kuroyuki - Goro - Chojiro - Gekkamaru. 
So it’s really up to you (:

I ended up loving them like this (from most favorite): Hanzo - Kuroyuki - Gekkamaru - Goro - Chojiro. 

The Protagonist: 

Enju was, without a doubt (and yes, I’m probably using this phrase a lot lately, sorry), one of the best things about this game. And I can’t say I’ve said this often about an otome game protagonists. 

She was at her very best in Hanzo’s route, but in every route she always showed us that fighting spirit of hers - the will to live and fight. 
And I couldn’t help but love her for that. 

She was obviously very mentally strong, but she was also physically capable of fighting - she just never knew she had it in her. 

What I admire most about a protagonist is their fighting spirit. Be in mentally, physically, or both, the will of the protagonist can do wonders to a game. 

Another thing: in otome games, it’s important to remember you can’t just develop the romance-able characters, you have to develop the protagonist throughout the game, too. Which is something i found lacking in many games, but not in Nightshade. Not at all.

So… WELL DONE. 
You went above and beyond for this protagonist. You made her the kind of protagonist I was proud to play as a character, and not just for the romance-able ones. 

When I think of this game, I end up not thinking about the guys - although I do - but of Enju (:

The Art:

The art… was… divine. 
The scenery was breathtaking. 
Every time I saw it I had to take it in for a few moments. 
It was so beautiful, it felt so magical yet so real, that I could literally see myself walking these paths, breathing that air, and missing a time I was never part of.

I cannot recommend this game enough. The art is absolutely gorgeous at first glance and I found myself eagerly returning to play just for that reason alone. 

The reason I like Nightshade so much is because the main 5 routes are not the only thing that it has going for them. Sure, I cried over the beautifully written main characters, but the side characters, Kyara, Ennosuke and Kasumi are nothing to turn your nose up at. They have a large part in making me bawl my eyes out almost every route. 

Surprisingly enough, I like the MC that you play as too; quite a lot. She has a reputation of being a quiet, but dedicated clan member - the daughter of the clan leader - and one of her things that I was instantly drawn to, is that she feels like she owes her clan absolutely everything, just for supporting her. Further in, it becomes apparent that she feels frustrated when she becomes a liability and will do just about anything to be useful. Depending on what route you choose, she can become a confident, assertive shinobi, or an uncertain, reliant on everyone person.

Speaking of which, the story is superb! Kudos to the writing team for thinking of something a little more imaginative than just your plain old 'she's a traitor, kill her'. I won't give too much away, but depending on the route that you choose early on, impacts which of the two stories are used (this will make sense after you play all the routes).

And the story...

There is no lack of content. Seriously. My first session which involved 1 and a half routes, was 915 minutes long. I kid you not. I played this beautiful game for the entire day because I just couldn't rip myself away from it. The music, the SFX, the characters and story THEY ARE ALL AT THE BEST QUALITY.

I didn't think that a VN would ever be able to pull off an intense fight scene, but thanks to the actual stakes of the fight, coupled with an MC WHO ACTUALLY FIGHTS WELL, I found myself enjoying the quicker paced scenes more than I thought I would. As another reviewer said before me THIS GAME MAKES STATIC ART INTERESTING. The use of the space was utilized to its utmost best. 

Pacing is good. The art. I've already gone off about it once, but I have never taken so many screenshots in a game before - and sometimes it was just of the same character with a different pose, or against a different background. Teita is a genius. I'll say this, if this game ever gets adapted into an anime, it would be worth the watch just for the art alone.

Bonus content awaits you after finishing one ending of a route which is very, VERY nice. Should I mention that you can choose which of the voice actors narrates the main menu? Because that's a thing.

Speaking of voice actors, THEY ARE SHINING GEMS. I could listen to their voices forever (shoutout to Kuroyuki's VA).

In conclusion, if you are a fan of otome games - perhaps Hakuouki in particular - then absolutely get Nightshade. I too, was a little 'is it REALLY worth it' over the slightly higher price compared to other titles, but I am completely and utterly satisfied with the product that I received, and I know I'll be playing this for many more tear-filled hours, long after I've received all the endings. You might play for the game, but you return for the characters.

I want to start by saying that for the most part I really did enjoy Nightshade. It’s a little tragic for an otome, but the artwork and characters are stunningly beautiful and it's a very well polished game overall - which isn't really surprising given the price. The voice acting is extensive and very emotionally impactful; it really adds to the quality of the experience and if you have yet to try a game that's fully voiced (in Japanese FYI) you should definitely give it a go. 

After reading a few reviews however, I couldn't find too many that really address how dissatisfying the game can be, so despite the thumbs up here I go. 

The story can be quite tragic, and when done properly it was very bittersweet, but more often than not I found it to be a bit jarring and at odds with the romantic character arcs. For example, the MC might have just witnessed [spoiler] the horrific deaths of people very close to her [/spoiler] and then moments later gets giddy and embarrassed because her crush held her hand? 

The routes share a couple of interesting twists but when you boil it all down that's pretty much it. Most of the game is spent [spoiler]running through woods and having random encounters with enemies.[/spoiler] All in all I can't say that's something that woud ever deter me from enjoying an otome game - I'd be lying if I said I'm here for the plot - but lumped together with a couple of other niggles makes it all a bit of a naggle (mixed experience). 

The protagonist is a bit floppy and does very little herself. I understand the need to be rescued every now and then, but when it’s done constantly by not just the love interest, but every single guy around (and always out of nowhere), it gets very old fast. She's a bit like a sack of flour that's just thrown around and hoisted over people's shoulders all the time. If she manages to [spoiler] take down a skilled enemy on her first mission, [/spoiler] why can’t she pull her head out of her ass and intervene, or even, god forbid, win, when people she cares about are threatened? 

Throughout the game it’s emphasised that Enju has less experience than some of the others and that she must be protected etc. In fact, this is probably her defining characteristic and the writers seem to have bent backwards trying to create excuses for why she can't do something herself when other outcomes would just make more sense. There seems to have been more effort put into Enju's intense phobia of having a spine than anything else in the game. This leaves her with very little impact on the world around her, especially for someone so central to the politics and schemes of the era. She should essentially be making some of these important decisions but she ends up spectating and then dressing wounds more than anything else (you’ll quickly find out for yourself that I’m really not exaggerating). 

No one buys an otome game expecting a highly realistic historical narrative, but when setting out any good story there should at least be some consistency in world building and characterisation.[spoiler]I have a sort of love hate thing going on for most otome games on the market and I'm just gonna shamelessly lay it out here because I'm so tired of seeing the same thing over and over again.[/spoiler]In almost all the routes, Enju has a lot of incentive to figure things out for herself or take action, but for a spy/assassin she’s shockingly dim and naïve, and it really irritated me to see that potential go to waste. I know it's pretty much the norm, but it would have been so satisfying to see a story crafted around someone capable and intelligent, filled with intrigue and espionage, without resorting to the classic born-yesterday-MC you find in every game. Her passive nature also makes almost every interaction feel one-sided or even kind of demeaning, which, barring a small niche demographic, can be very uncomfortable to read as a player.

Generally speaking, the characters are sweet and often likeable, especially the MC as she puts herself above others and it manages to come off as genuine thoughtfulness without being too irritating. As a protagonist, I thought her design and background were quite unique and it's nice to at least be an actual shinobi instead of the usual princess or bystander. A number of the scenes the characters all have together are funny and set up emotional attachments for the player, but the dialogue does feel a little padded out sometimes. There was a lot of exposition and occasionally the more dramatic scenes were very repetitive or lasted far longer than they needed to. Conversations often go in circles and everyone keeps saying the same thing over and over in different ways - not for dramatic effect but just... because? Not to mention a lot of the "mysteries" are not very mysterious at all and I'm pretty sure a 7 year old with a decent grasp of logic would be able to understand everything before the MC does. I'm not sure if this is all done under the assumption that teenage girls will somehow not be able to handle a more complicated narrative, or if the developers are just sticking to the "delayed-reactions-are-easier-than-plots" otome gold standard, but it does come off as a little insulting sometimes.

Let me get straight to gushing about the game's characters.  While I wasn't in love with each and every one of the obtainable love interests right off the bat, most were interesting and likeable enough for me to seek out the resolution to their individual storylines.  Yes, all of the standard character tropes are present, and although Nightshade doesn't break any boundaries when it comes to its romances, it does them well.  And honestly, that's all I'm really looking for out of these games, well-written romances.  Of course, while some of the guys are more appealing than others (Goemon and Hanzo), there's at least one that will have you completely smitten by the end, maybe two.  

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=918425771
When it comes to artwork, the game is stunning.  The character sprites are not only amazingly detailed but feature emotive facial movements that lip sync to the dialogue.  Although this isn't the first time a VN has accomplished the feat, it's always appreciated and certainly helps bring the characters to life.  Nightshade's CGs are some of the best in the genre and are not only beautifully drawn but emotionally poignant, wonderfully emphasizing the more dramatic scenes in the story.  The dialogue and voice work are also top notch with fluid writing and believable acting.  Seiyus generally do not make or break a game for me; if they're bad or distracting, I simply turn them off, no big deal.  I do admit they're really good here, and it helped immerse me in the times I felt my immersion beginning to wane.  

Unfortunately, where Nightshade stumbles is in the plot department.  Granted, I've read worse otome stories, much worse, but there is WAY too much repetition in the sequence of events that follows the common route chapters.  Sure, there are some minor changes in details, but for the most part Enju spends a good portion of the game traveling through the forest evading capture by the same 3-4 shinobi clans.  It isn't until the final chapters that things change enough to rekindle my interest, but it's just not enough to keep me engaged past the 3rd character route.  By my 4th and 5th play through I had shut off my brain's story "receptors" and was merely hoping the relationship between Enju and her beau would quickly move beyond hand holding. Whatever the case, I feel a little empty now thinking how this beautiful game didn't quite live up to my lofty expectations. Главная героиня с друзьями-синоби отправляется на своё первое задание. Но что-то, разумеется, идёт не так, и теперь девушке предстоит пройти долгий путь, чтобы понять, кто друг, а кто враг, что вообще произошло и как теперь быть.

По ходу развития сюжета героиня взрослеет, умнеет, становится лучше. Это увлекательно — наблюдать за становлением личности. Конечно, без слёз и трогательных моментов не обходится, потому что она человек, у неё доброе сердце и она любит своих друзей.

Отдельно хочется порекомендовать рут Хандзо — он душевный, притягательный, яркий и, пожалуй, один из самых логичных по развитию романа с главной героиней. Вообще романтика в игре потрясающая: нам не подают избранника на блюдечке с золотой каёмочкой. TL;DR Nightshade is the equivalent of an AAA game in the otome world, and absolutely worth its price.

First for an overview.
Nightshade is a visual novel on what it means to be a shinobi in the Sengoku era of Japan, during a time of tentative balance teering on the brink of change. The main character (I strongly recommend keeping the canon name Enju since the other characters will actually say her name) is a girl who is determined to give back to her shinobi village, and finds herself way in over her head in a conspiracy. 

There are five routes the story can take, each involving a romance between Enju and a specific shinobi man. Each route is the perfect length IMO, not too long and not too short. In total, the game should probably take between 18 to 30 hours depending on the speed of your reading. There are a total of five routes--2 of which are angsty, 2 of which are hopeful, and a third in-between (slightly more on the hopeful side though).


Pros:
-The historical Sengoku era and shinobi aesthetic is very cool even for someone who knows basically nothing about the historical figures (but was inspired to look them up more after finishing the game.). 

-Writing across the board is high quality, with each route taking their own spin on the game's overarching theme--what in the life of a shinobi is truly worth living/fighting/dying for. Suspense and tension are very nicely maintained. The stories know when to be serious and when to be playful, so this consistency in tone is reassuring. Some plot threads are picked up and then dropped, but that is pretty natural to any visual novel with multiple diverging routes and in this game it never occurs on a truly bothersome scale. Overall it's extremely easy to immerse yourself in the story IMO.

-Character development can be absolutely superb in some routes. The side characters are great fun to have around and also ripe for drama of their own. I can say that in every route, the main characters change in a believably human way with consistent motivations and goals.

-Voice acting is stellar. They shelled out for the VAs, and it shows. Every main character has a perfectly fitting voice. You can even choose which character's voice you want to hear when you're navigating the main menu! I do wish Enju herself was voiced, but oh well. 

-Visuals are generally beautiful. The portraits are gorgeous, the backgrounds are lush. Teita's art style fits this game perfectly. Even the fight scenes are somehow very captivating despite the typical visual novel limitations (can only be written with portraits blinking around, clashing noises, etc.)

-Soundtrack is good overall. There was one screeching guitar track I disliked during action scenes, but that was the only one of its ilk, while there is a particular dramatic action track I absolutely loved. 


Possible cons? Your mileage will vary on whether these are negative or even positive. 
-Story only has a single very fundamental premise. Of note, there is one /giant/ branching point early in the story that divvies out the five routes into two branches. The plots and reveals of the two branches are fundamentally different. However, there are two routes in the same branch that have quite similar stories, so if you do one your suspense during the other will be significantly decreased. 

-Some routes get more closure in terms of the overarching story than others. However, I can say that every route does achieve closure. Often the routes that didn't get that "overarching story closure" often received far more satisfying "individual journey closure," so it's not a strictly bad thing.

-Just like every otome game (nay, every visual novel) in existence, some character archetypes will naturally appeal to you more than others. As a result, most people find themselves with one or two favorite routes that they want to reread over and over. Those one or two routes alone could justify the entire price of the game :P On the other hand, this means most people also find themselves with one or two routes that are unappealing. 

-UI can be a bit clunky, but it's tolerable and very much usable. It has the much appreciated industry standard options of Quick Save/Load, see the previous script, jump back to an earlier scene, etc. 

Other notes:

-There were text readability issues for the first few days, but it has been fixed. I can safely say that right now the text is perfectly comfortable to read. 




One last word, don't let looks deceive you--Hanzo is the cutest boy in the cast.

* Writing and execution of the storyline was a strong point of the game

Cons: 

* Main linear storyline is prevalent in all the routes (common route is the same for all characters)
* Game branch diverges into two linear story paths. 
* Although there are alternate events and different endings for all the characters, the core events of the storyline are repetitive. This makes the game become rapidly stale by around the third or fourth playthrough.

* The character routes are not fully disconnected from one another, and they all build from the same premise.

I found Nightshade to be a beautiful game with amazing art by Teita, one of my favorite otome game artists, as well as amazing voicing, incredible soundtrack and an interesting main plot with a dark touch (as I do love my dark otome games).

Nightshade is a ninja otome game. You play as Ueno Enju (given name changeable), the village chief's daughter who's going on her first mission. This game is one of the kind of otome games where you end up on someone's route depending on which one's affection you gain more of, and the five characters are: Gekkamaru, Kuroyuki, Choujirou, Hanzou and Goemon.

Gekkamaru - Gekkamaru is Enju's...bodyguard. He's a super sweet guy who worries about her a lot, and always tries to protect her to the point where she has to sneak away from him to be able train herself as a ninja. Gekkamaru's route is more of the "truth" route, where you discover why Enju's in the situation that she's been entangled in, and should definitely be played last.

Kuroyuki - Kuroyuki is Gekkamaru's younger brother who's apparently always liked her. He was sent away on a mission a long time ago, and returns just in time to join in on Enju's first mission. Despite his playful appearance, throughout his route, he's revealed to also be quite deceitful, though also very protective of Enju and envious of his brother for being the one who was chosen to be her bodyguard. To me, after Gekkamaru, Kuroyuki's route was the darkest.

Choujirou - Enju's cousin and a very skilled ninja, Choujirou is the one who trains Enju. In his route, he's in a constant battle between his feelings he's developed for Enju, and his duty as a ninja. After Gekkamaru's route, I'd say his route is the saddest.

Hanzou - Hanzou is a powerful ninja who's duty is to protect Tokugawa Ieyasu. In his route, he is sent on a mission to protect Enju for the time being, and simultaneously trains Enju and helps her grow as a ninja. Under his tutelage, Enju becomes a much stronger ninja and is able to confront a painful truth about her situation.

Goemon - Goemon is a thief who steals valuables from the rich and noble a**holes, basically a Robin Hood. He's an easy-going guy who bumps into Enju from time to time and kind of distracts her from her goal of collecting more information for her mission.

After playing through everything, the order I recommend you play is Goemon, Hanzou, Kuroyuki, Choujirou, then Gekkamaru, which I believe is going from lighter and slowly getting darker, as the closer the characters are to Enju overall, the darker the route seems to be. It's really up to you what order you're going to play, however, definitely play Gekkamaru's route LAST for the final big reveal kind of thing.

Overall, I did find the game a little short, however, I would certainly recommend it if you like the darkish otome games, or ninja otome games.
